question: To maintain altitude, what must be done as Indicated Air Speed (IAS) is reduced:

choices.choice: Decrease angle of attack to reduce the drag.
Increase angle of attack to maintain the correct lift force.
Deploy the speed brakes to increase drag.
Reduce thrust.

explanation:
from the lift equation:

l = (1/2) * ρ * v² * cₗ * s

  • as indicated airspeed (IAS) decreases, the dynamic pressure (1/2)∗ρ∗v2
  • to maintain constant lift (l) and altitude, the coefficient of lift (cₗ) must increase.
  • the only way to increase cₗ is by increasing the angle of attack (aoa).

however, increasing aoa has a limit, as excessive aoa can lead to stall.
subject: Technical

question: If more lift force is required because of greater operating weight, what must be done to fly at the angle of attack which corresponds to CLMAX:

choices.choice: Increase the angle of attack.
Nothing, the angle of attack for CLMAX is constant.
It is impossible to fly at the angle of attack that corresponds to CLMAX.
Increase the Indicated Air Speed (IAS).

explanation:
the angle of attack for cₗmax is constant for a given airfoil. however, lift (l) must increase to support a higher weight. from the lift equation:

l = (1/2) * ρ * v² * cₗ * s

  • since cₗmax remains constant, the only way to generate more lift is by increasing ias (v).
  • this ensures that the aircraft can produce enough lift without exceeding the critical angle of attack, preventing a stall.
subject: Technical

question: Which of the following statements is correct:

choices.choice: To generate a constant lift force, any adjustment in IAS must be accompanied by a change in angle of attack.
For a constant lift force, each IAS requires a specific angle of attack.
Minimum IAS is determined by CLMAX.
The greater the operating weight, the higher the minimum IAS.

explanation: As weight increases, more lift is required to maintain level flight. since cₗmax is fixed, the only way to generate more lift is by increasing ias. this means that the minimum ias (stall speed) increases with higher weight.
subject: Technical

question: What effect does landing at high altitude airports have on ground speed with comparable conditions relative to temperature, wind, and aeroplane weight:

choices.choice: Higher than at low altitude.
The same as at low altitude.
Lower than at low altitude.
Dynamic pressure will be the same at any altitude.

explanation: At high-altitude airports, air density (ρ) is lower, which means for the same indicated airspeed (ias), the true airspeed (tas) is higher. since ground speed = tas ± wind, and there is no wind difference, the ground speed will be higher compared to landing at a low-altitude airport.
subject: Technical

question: What flight condition should be expected when an aircraft leaves ground effect:

choices.choice: A decrease in parasite drag permitting a lower angle of attack.
An increase in induced drag and a requirement for a higher angel of attack.
An increase in dynamic stability.
A decrease in induced drag requiring a smaller angle of attack.

explanation: When an aircraft leaves ground effect (the area within approximately one wingspan of the surface), it experiences a decrease in lift due to the loss of reduced wingtip vortices and downwash, which had previously enhanced effective lift. This results in an increase in induced drag, as stronger vortices form once the aircraft moves away from the surface. To compensate for the reduced lift, the aircraft must increase its angle of attack, which further contributes to drag. Consequently, more thrust is required to maintain flight, making this transition particularly noticeable during takeoff and initial climb.
subject: Technical

question: What will be the ratio between airspeed and lift if the angle of attack and other factors remain constant and airspeed is doubled. Lift will be:

choices.choice: Two times greater.
Four times greater
The same.
One quarter.

explanation:
Lift equation:
l = (1/2) ρ v² s c_l

Where:

  • l = lift
  • ρ = air density
  • v = airspeed
  • s = wing area
  • c_l = coefficient of lift

If airspeed (v) is doubled, lift increases by the square of the velocity change:

l’ = (1/2) ρ (2v)² s c_l = 4l

Thus, lift becomes four times greater when airspeed is doubled.
subject: Technical

question: What true airspeed and angle of attack should be used to generate the same amount of lift as altitude is increased:

choices.choice: A higher true airspeed for any given angle of attack.
The same true airspeed and angle of attack.
A lower true airspeed and higher angle of attack.
A constant angle of attack and true air speed.

explanation:
As altitude increases, air density (ρ\rhoρ) decreases, which reduces lift according to the lift equation:

l = (1/2) ρ v² s c_l

Where:

  • l = lift
  • ρ = air density
  • v = airspeed
  • s = wing area
  • c_l = coefficient of lift

To compensate for the lower air density and maintain the same lift, true airspeed (TAS) must be increased while keeping the angle of attack constant. This ensures that the dynamic pressure remains sufficient to generate the required lift.
subject: Technical

question: How can an aeroplane produce the same lift in ground effect as when out of ground effect:

choices.choice: A lower angle of attack.
A higher angle of attack.
The same angle of attack.
The same angle of attack, but a lower IAS.

explanation: In ground effect, induced drag decreases due to reduced wingtip vortices and downwash. This increases effective lift for the same angle of attack. To produce the same lift as in free air, the aircraft requires a lower angle of attack in ground effect.
subject: Technical

question: By changing the angle of attack of a wing, the pilot can control the aeroplane’s:

choices.choice: Lift and airspeed, but not drag.
Lift, gross weight, and drag.
Lift, airspeed, and drag.
Lift and drag, but not airspeed.

explanation: By increasing the angle of attack, lift increases up to a certain point (before stall), but drag also increases, reducing airspeed. Conversely, decreasing the angle of attack reduces lift and drag, allowing airspeed to increase. Thus, changing the angle of attack affects lift, airspeed, and drag.
subject: Technical

question: Which flight conditions of a large jet aeroplane create the most severe flight hazard by generating wingtip vortices of the greatest strength:

choices.choice: Heavy, slow, gear and flaps up.
Heavy, fast, gear and flaps down.
Heavy, slow, gear and flaps down.
Weight, gear and flaps, make no difference.

explanation:
Wingtip vortices are swirling columns of air that form at the tips of an aircraft’s wings due to the pressure difference between the upper (low pressure) and lower (high pressure) surfaces of the wing. As the higher-pressure air from below the wing moves outward and curls around the wingtip to the lower-pressure region above, it creates rotational airflow, generating vortices.

Wingtip vortices are strongest when an aircraft is heavy, flying slowly, and in a clean configuration (gear and flaps up) because:

  1. Heavy – More lift is required, leading to stronger vortices.
  2. Slow – A higher angle of attack is needed to maintain lift, intensifying vortex strength.
  3. Gear and flaps up (clean configuration) – High-lift devices (flaps) disrupt vortex formation, so vortices are strongest in clean flight.
subject: Technical

question: Hazardous vortex turbulence that might be encountered behind large aircraft is created only when that aircraft is:

choices.choice: Using high power settings.
Operating at high airspeeds.
Developing lift.
Operating at high altitude.

explanation: Wingtip vortices form due to the pressure difference between the upper and lower surfaces of a wing. These vortices are generated whenever an aircraft is producing lift, meaning they are present in all phases of flight where lift is required.
subject: Technical

question: Wingtip vortices created by large aircraft tend to:

choices.choice: Rise from the surface to traffic pattern altitude.
Skin below the aircraft generating the turbulence.
Accumulate and remain for a period of time at the point where the takeoff roll began.
Dissipate very slowly when the surface wind is strong.

explanation: Trailing vortices typically remain separated by about three-quarters of the aircraft’s wingspan. In still air, they drift slowly downward and usually level off between 500 and 1000 feet below the flight path of the generating aircraft. Behind a large aircraft, wake turbulence can extend up to nine nautical miles, posing a significant hazard to following aircraft, especially in calm wind conditions. Proper separation and avoidance techniques are essential to mitigate the risks associated with wake turbulence.
subject: Technical

question: How does the wake turbulence vortex circulate around each wingtip, when viewed from the rear:

choices.choice: Inward, upward, and around the wingtip.
Counterclockwise.
Outward, upward, and around the wingtip.
Outward, downward and around the wingtip.

explanation: Wake turbulence vortices form due to the pressure difference between the upper (low pressure) and lower (high pressure) surfaces of the wing. As a result, air moves outward, upward, and around the wingtip toward the low-pressure area above. When viewed from the rear, the right wingtip vortex rotates counterclockwise, while the left wingtip vortex rotates clockwise. These vortices descend and spread outward behind the aircraft, posing a wake turbulence hazard for following aircraft.
subject: Technical

question: Which statement is true concerning the wake turbulence produced by a large transport aircraft:

choices.choice: Wake turbulence behind a propeller-driven aircraft is negligible because jet engine thrust is a necessary factor in the formation of vortices.
Vortices can be avoided by flying 300 feet below and behind the flightpath of the generating aircraft.
The vortex characteristics of any given aircraft may be altered by extending the flaps or changing the speed.
Vortices can be avoided by flying downwind of, and below the flight path of the generating aircraft.

explanation: Wake turbulence is caused by wingtip vortices, which result from the pressure difference between the upper and lower surfaces of a wing. Flap extension alters the wing’s lift distribution, reducing vortex strength by increasing wing span efficiency and decreasing the wingtip pressure difference. Speed changes affect vortex intensity—lower speeds generate stronger vortices due to the higher angle of attack required to maintain lift.
subject: Technical

question: What effect would a light crosswind have on the wingtip vortices generated by a large aeroplane that has just taken off:

choices.choice: The downwind vortex will tend to remain on the runway longer than the upwind vortex.
A crosswind will rapidly dissipate the strength of both vortices.
A crosswind will move both vertices clear of the runway.
The upwind vortex will tend to remain on the runway longer than the downwind vortex.

explanation:
In a crosswind, if the surface wind is light and steady, the wake vortex system “in contact” with the ground will drift with the wind.

The upwind vortex will tend to remain on the runway longer than the downwind vortex. In a light crosswind, the wake vortex system drifts with the wind. The downwind vortex moves away from the runway more quickly, while the upwind vortex lingers longer over the runway, posing a greater risk to following aircraft.
subject: Technical

question: To avoid the wingtip vortices of a departing jet aeroplane during takeoff, the pilot should:

choices.choice: Remain below the flightpath of the jet aeroplane.
Climb above and stay upwind of the jet aeroplane's flightpath.
Lift off at a point well past the jet aeroplane's flightpath.
Remain below and downwind of the jet aeroplane's flightpath.

explanation: To avoid the wingtip vortices of a departing jet aeroplane during takeoff, the pilot should climb above and stay upwind of the jet aeroplane’s flightpath. This is because wingtip vortices tend to sink and drift with the wind. By climbing above, the pilot avoids the descending vortices, and by staying upwind, the aircraft remains clear of the area where the vortices are likely to be carried.
subject: Technical

question: what wind condition prolongs the hazards of wake turbulence on a landing runway for the longest period of time:

choices.choice: Light quartering headwind.
Light quartering tailwind.
Direct tailwind.
Strong, direct crosswind.

explanation:
A light quartering tailwind can prolong the hazards of wake turbulence for the longest time because:

  • Wake vortices sink and drift with the wind.

  • In light wind conditions, especially with a tailwind component, the vortices can linger over the runway instead of moving away quickly.

  • A quartering tailwind may cause the vortices to remain in the touchdown zone or drift across it slowly, increasing the risk for following aircraft.
subject: Technical

question: If you take off behind a heavy jet that has landed, you should plan to lift off:

choices.choice: Prior to the point where the jet touched down.
At the point where the jet touched down and on the upwind edge of the runway.
Before the point where the jet touched down and on the downwind edge of the runway.
Beyond the point where the jet touched down.

explanation: Lifting off beyond the touchdown point of a heavy jet helps you avoid its lingering wake turbulence, particularly wingtip vortices that settle and persist near the ground in the touchdown zone. By rotating past this area, you reduce the risk of encountering these hazardous air currents during your takeoff roll and initial climb.
subject: Technical

question: The adverse effects of ice, snow, or frost on aircraft performance and flight characteristics include decreased lift and:

choices.choice: Increased thrust.
A decreased stall speed.
An increased stall speed.
An aircraft will always stall at the same indicated airspeed.

explanation: Ice and snow on wings increase stall speed because they alter the airfoil’s shape, disrupting the smooth airflow over the surface. This leads to a decrease in lift and an increase in drag. As a result, the wing stalls at a lower angle of attack but requires a higher airspeed than normal to maintain flight. This combination significantly impairs performance and safety, especially during critical phases like takeoff and landing.
subject: Technical

question: Lift on a wing is most properly defined as the:

choices.choice: Differential pressure acting perpendicular to the chord of the wing.
Force acting perpendicular to the relative wind.
Reduced pressure resulting from a laminar flow over the upper camber of an aerofoil, which acts perpendicular to the mean camber.
Force acting parallel with the relative wind and in the opposite direction.

explanation: Lift is most properly defined as the aerodynamic force that acts perpendicular to the relative wind (or the flight path of the aircraft). It results from the pressure difference between the upper and lower surfaces of the wing, generated by the airflow over the airfoil.
subject: Technical

question: Which statement is true relative to changing angle of attack:

choices.choice: A decrease in angle of attack will increase pressure below the wing, and decrease drag.
An increase in angle of attack will decrease pressure below the wing, and increase drag.
An increase in angle of attack will increase drag.
An increase in angle of attack will decrease the lift coefficient.

explanation: Increasing the angle of attack (AOA) generally leads to an increase in drag, especially induced drag, which is caused by the greater deflection of airflow and stronger wingtip vortices. However, this is true only up to a certain point. At higher AOA, the airflow can separate from the upper surface, causing a stall. This results in a sharp rise in drag and a loss of lift, which is critical to flight performance and control.
subject: Technical

question: The angle of attack of a wing directly controls the:

choices.choice: Angle of incidence of the wing.
Distribution of pressures acting on the wing.
Amount of airflow above and below the wing.
Dynamic pressure acting in the airflow.

explanation: The angle of attack (AOA) is the angle between the chord line of the wing and the relative airflow. Changing the AOA directly affects how air flows over and under the wing, which in turn alters the pressure distribution on the wing surfaces. This is what controls lift and ultimately influences stall and drag characteristics.
subject: Technical

question: In theory, if the angle of attack and other factors remain constant and the airspeed is doubled, the lift produced at the higher speed will be;

choices.choice: The same as at the lower speed.
Two times greater than at the lower speed.
Four times greater than at the lower speed.
One quarter as much.

explanation:
Lift is calculated using the lift equation:

Lift = (1/2) × ρ × V² × S × CL

Where:

  • ρ = air density

  • V = airspeed

  • S = wing area

  • CL = coefficient of lift (depends on angle of attack)

If angle of attack and other factors remain constant, then CL, ρ, and S are constant. So:

Lift ∝ V²

That means if the airspeed is doubled:

(2V)² = 4V²

So, the lift becomes four times greater.
subject: Technical

question: An aircraft wing is designed to produce lift resulting from a difference in the:

choices.choice: Negative air pressure below and a vacuum above the wing's surface.
Vacuum below the wing's surface and greater air pressure above the wing's surface.
Higher air pressure below the wing's surface and lower air pressure above the wing's surface.
Higher pressure at the leading edge than at the trailing edge.

explanation:
An aircraft wing generates lift primarily due to the pressure difference created between the upper and lower surfaces of the wing:

  • As air flows over the curved upper surface, it accelerates, causing the pressure to drop (Bernoulli’s Principle).

  • Meanwhile, air moving under the flatter lower surface moves more slowly, creating higher pressure below.

This pressure difference results in an upward force, known as lift.
subject: Technical

question: Which statement is true, regarding the opposing forces acting on an aeroplane in steady-state level flight:

choices.choice: Thrust is greater than drag and weight and lift are equal.
These forces are equal.
Thrust is greater than drag and lift is greater than weight.
Thrust is slightly greater than Lift, but the drag and weight are equal.

explanation:
In steady-state level flight, an aircraft is neither accelerating nor climbing or descending. This means:

  • Thrust = Drag → no acceleration forward or backward

  • Lift = Weight → no climb or descent

This balance of forces is what defines steady, level, unaccelerated flight.
subject: Technical

question: At higher elevation airports the pilot should know that indicated airspeed:

choices.choice: Will be unchanged, but ground speed will be faster.
Will be higher, but ground speed will be unchanged.
Should be increased to compensate for the thinner air.
Should be higher to obtain a higher landing speed.

explanation:
At higher elevation airports, the air density is lower due to altitude. However:

  • Indicated Airspeed (IAS) is based on air pressure and remains unchanged for a given aerodynamic performance (e.g., stall speed, takeoff speed).

  • True Airspeed (TAS) and Ground Speed (GS) increase because the aircraft must move faster through the thinner air to achieve the same IAS.

So, while your IAS stays the same, your GS is higher, which means longer takeoff and landing distances.
subject: Technical

question: An aeroplane leaving ground effect will:

choices.choice: Experience a reduction in ground friction and require a slight power reduction.
Require a lower angle of attack to maintain the same lift coefficient.
Experience a reduction in induced drag and require a smaller angle of attack.
Experience an increase in induced drag and require more thrust.

explanation:
When an aircraft leaves ground effect, the following occurs:

  • Induced drag increases: Ground effect reduces the strength of wingtip vortices and downwash, which lowers induced drag. Leaving ground effect restores full vortex strength, increasing induced drag.

  • Thrust requirement increases: More induced drag means the engines need to produce more thrust to maintain the same performance.

  • Angle of attack must be increased: To maintain the same lift (CL), the pilot typically has to increase angle of attack, since lift reduces when leaving ground effect.

So, the aircraft will need more thrust and experience more induced drag after climbing out of ground effect.
subject: Technical

question: Which is true regarding the force of lift in steady, unaccelerated flight:

choices.choice: There is a corresponding indicated airspeed required for every angle of attack to generate sufficient lift to maintain altitude.
An aerofoil will always stall at the same indicated airspeed; therefore, an increase in weight will require an increase in speed to generate sufficient lift to maintain altitude.
At lower airspeeds the angle of attack must be less to generate sufficient lift to maintain altitude.
The lift force must be exactly equal to the drag force.

explanation: In steady, unaccelerated flight, the lift generated by the wings must equal the weight of the aircraft to maintain level flight. The amount of lift produced depends on both the angle of attack and the indicated airspeed. For each specific angle of attack, there is a corresponding indicated airspeed that will generate the required lift to keep the aircraft at a constant altitude. As the angle of attack increases, the indicated airspeed can decrease, and vice versa, ensuring that the right balance of lift is maintained for level flight.
subject: Technical

question: At a given Indicated Air Speed, what effect will an increase in air density have on lift and drag:

choices.choice: Lift will increase but drag will decrease.
Lift and drag will increase.
Lift and drag will decrease.
Lift and drag will remain the same.

explanation: At a constant Indicated Airspeed (IAS), lift and drag depend on dynamic pressure, which is influenced by air density. Since IAS is held constant, dynamic pressure remains the same, meaning both lift and drag do not change despite variations in air density. Therefore, changes in air density do not affect the lift and drag at a given IAS.
subject: Technical

question: If the angle of attack is increased beyond the critical angle of attack, the wing will no longer produce sufficient lift to support the weight of the aircraft:

choices.choice: Unless the airspeed is greater than the normal stall speed.
Regardless of airspeed or pitch attitude.
Unless the pitch attitude is on or below the natural horizon.
In which case, the control column should be pulled-back immediately.

explanation: When the angle of attack exceeds the critical angle of attack (also known as the stall angle), the airflow over the wing becomes turbulent, causing a stall. This loss of lift occurs regardless of airspeed or pitch attitude. The wing can no longer generate sufficient lift, leading to the aircraft potentially losing altitude and requiring immediate recovery actions, such as lowering the nose to reduce the angle of attack.
subject: Technical

question: Given That: Aircraft A. Wingspan: 51 m, Average wing chord: 4 m, Aircraft B. Wingspan: 48 m, Average wing chord: 3.5 m. Determine the correct aspect ratio and wing area.

choices.choice: Aircraft A has an aspect ratio of 13.7, and has a larger wing area than aircraft B.
Aircraft B has an aspect ratio of 13.7, and has a smaller wing area than aircraft A.
Aircraft B has an aspect ratio of 12.75, and has a smaller wing area than aircraft A.
Aircraft A has an aspect ratio of 12.75, and has a smaller wing area than aircraft B.

explanation:
Aspect Ratio Formula:
AR = b / c
Where:
AR = Aspect Ratio
b = Wingspan
c = Average Chord

Wing Area Formula:
S = b × c
Where:
b = Wingspan
c = Average Chord

Aircraft A:

  • Wingspan b = 51 m

  • Average chord c = 4 m

Wing Area:
S_A = 51 × 4 = 204 m²

Aspect Ratio:
AR_A = 51 / 4 = 12.75

Aircraft B:

  • Wingspan b = 48 m

  • Average chord c = 3.5 m

Wing Area:
S_B = 48 × 3.5 = 168 m²

Aspect Ratio:
AR_B = 48 / 3.5 ≈ 13.7


Aircraft B has an aspect ratio of 13.7 and a smaller wing area than Aircraft A.
subject: Technical

question: Aspect ratio of the wing is defined as the ratio of the:

choices.choice: Wingspan to the wing root.
Square of the chord to the wing span.
Wing span to the average chord.
Square of the wing area to the span.

explanation: Aspect ratio is defined as the ratio of the wingspan to the average chord. It is a measure of the “elongation” of the wing, and higher aspect ratios generally result in more efficient wings with lower drag.
subject: Technical

question: What changes to aircraft control must be made to maintain altitude while the airspeed is being decreased:

choices.choice: Increase the angle of attack to compensate for the decreasing dynamic pressure.
Maintain a constant angle of attack until the desired airspeed is reached, then increase the angle of attack.
Increase angle of attack to produce more lift than weight.
Decrease the angle of attack to compensate for the decrease in drag.

explanation: As the airspeed decreases, the dynamic pressure (which directly influences lift) also decreases. To maintain altitude, the angle of attack must be increased to generate enough lift to counterbalance the aircraft’s weight. This compensates for the reduction in dynamic pressure at lower speeds.
subject: Technical

question: Take-off from an airfield with a low density altitude will result in:

choices.choice: a longer take-off run.
a higher than standard IAS before lift off.
a higher TAS for the same lift off IAS.
a shorter take off run because of the lower TAS required for the same IAS.

explanation:
Low density altitude refers to thicker, denser air, which typically occurs in conditions of low temperature, high atmospheric pressure, and low humidity.

  • In low density altitude conditions (thicker air), the aircraft’s wings generate more lift at a lower speed. This means that for the same Indicated Airspeed (IAS), the aircraft will need less True Airspeed (TAS) to achieve sufficient lift-off speed.

  • Since the aircraft can reach take-off speed more efficiently in denser air, the take-off run becomes shorter compared to higher density altitudes.
subject: Technical
